thread.title: Wet stops production at Northern Territory gold mine
thread.title_full: Wet stops production at Northern Territory gold mine

author: Katrina Beavan
title: Wet stops production at Northern Territory gold mine
text:
Map: Yuendumu 0872 
Many of the roads are still cut in and around Central Australia thanks to recent wet weather, including the Tanami Road. 
It means the Granites Gold Mine has had no road access for 57 days and have not been able to truck enough diesel in. 
Francois Hardy, General Manager at Newmont Tanami Operations, said production had now stopped and minimal staff were on site. 
"We're down to about 100 people on site, and all they're really doing is just making sure that we don't have any releases in the environment and that we preserve the mine, [so] that once we do have diesel on site we can ramp up production again," Mr Hardy said. 
"We stopped the process plant last weekend [and] on the 10th of February we'll be flying all non-essential staff that remain on site [out]. 
"A number of them are undergoing training and the like in Perth next week, and the rest of them are currently still being paid to be available on a standby basis so that the second we do get diesel back on site we can bring them back in and we can ramp up production again." Photo: The mill at the Newmont Granites Gold Mine, 500 kilometres north-west of Alice Springs. (Caddie Brain) 
Mr Hardy said the mine usually had around 600 people on site at any one time. 
"We don't have anyone going underground anymore and we only have power to keep pumps going so we don't flood the mine," he said. 
"At the processing plant we've actually stopped and all we have at the moment is people doing maintenance. 
"We only started losing production effectively from last Saturday, the 4th of February. 
"For every week that we're down, we're losing about 8,000 ounces." 
"I'm hoping that we can be up and running by the end of next week, two weeks maximum [all up] I'm hoping, obviously. It's all weather dependant." Road closure end in sight 
Mr Hardy said the company was hoping the road would open up on the Halls Creek side in WA sometime next week, while the road on the Alice Springs side in the NT was estimated to be closed for another two to three weeks. 
He said looking at their records, this is the longest they had ever been cut off. 
"At the beginning of 2014 we were cut off for 31 days. At this stage it's been 57 days that we've been cut off," he said. 
"We have had heavier rain, heavier downpours at times, but never this consistent." 
As for whether or not this was the catalyst for sealing the Tanami Road, Mr Hardy said it would never be justified based on the mine's impact, but rather the local people driving back and forth between Yuendumu and Lajamanu. 
"I don't have people driving back and forth on that road, it's only our deliveries to site. And typically we do account for about six weeks of delays on and off during the wet season."
